phrases.text: Hi, is this the bus to...?
phrases.usage: Use this helpful question to check with a stranger if the bus travels to your destination.
phrases.example: Hi, is this the bus to the central park?

phrases.usage: Use this socially helpful response when you believe the information is correct but are not certain.
phrases.example: Yes, I think so. The sign says city center.

phrases.usage: Use this phrase to explain your daily routine and destination during a polite morning conversation.
phrases.example: I go to work at the big blue office.

phrases.usage: Use this to tell a fellow passenger where you are heading if you are a student today.
phrases.example: I go to school to study new modern languages.

phrases.usage: Use this to share helpful information about the bus schedule based on your typical daily experience.
phrases.example: It usually comes at eight o'clock in the morning.

phrases.usage: Use this to start small talk about the current situation when the transport is behind schedule.
phrases.example: It's late today because the busy traffic is very slow.

phrases.usage: Use this friendly follow-up question to learn more about the person you are chatting with.
phrases.example: Where are you going on this very cold rainy day?

phrases.usage: Use this kind and polite closing phrase to finish your conversation before you get off.
phrases.example: Have a good day and enjoy the bright warm sun.

keyVocabulary.definition: When there are too many people in one small place.
Something that is good and always works or arrives on time.
Happening or starting many times in a short period.
Happening later than the time that was first planned.
Something that is nice, enjoyable, or very friendly.
